title: Writing Portfolio Celebration — Sharing Our Words with the World
description: Students finalize their creative writing portfolios with a decorative cover, author biography, and dedication page. They present their completed portfolio to family members in a mini author celebration, experiencing the pride of being a published writer.
instructions:
1. 'Your writing portfolio is almost complete! Today we add the finishing touches that make it truly special.'
2. Create an author biography page: 'About the Author' with a self-portrait, name, age, hobbies, and favorite books.
3. Write a dedication page: 'This book is dedicated to ___ because ___'
4. Design a decorative cover with:
   - A compelling title for the portfolio
   - Author name
   - Beautiful illustration
   - Year
5. Add a back cover with a brief 'blurb' about the portfolio's contents.
6. Assemble the complete portfolio in order: cover, dedication, table of contents, writing pieces with author's notes, biography, back cover.
7. Present the finished portfolio to family in a mini author celebration.
8. Read one favorite piece aloud to the audience.
9. Sign copies (the front page) as a real author would.
10. 'You are a published author. These are YOUR words, YOUR stories, YOUR voice.'

slides.heading: My Published Portfolio
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "My Published Portfolio" and "A Writer's Celebration." This means your amazing writing is all finished and ready to be shared, just like a real author's book!

slides.setup_instructions: Have the writing portfolio from last week ready with all selected pieces. Prepare card stock for covers, art supplies for decoration, and binding materials. Arrange a mini celebration space for the presentation.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we're getting our supplies ready for our writer's celebration! We have your writing portfolio from last week, cool card stock for covers, colorful markers and pencils to draw with, things to make a self-portrait, glue or tape to stick everything together, and ribbon to tie it all up. We also need our family audience to be here to celebrate with us!

slides.text: Create the author biography: 'Every book has an About the Author page. Draw a self-portrait and write about yourself: your name, your age, your hobbies, your favorite books, and what you love about writing. This tells readers who YOU are.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us how to make the special "About the Author" page for your portfolio! It's like telling everyone who the amazing writer is behind all these stories. You'll draw a picture of yourself and write your name, how old you are, what fun things you like to do, and what your favorite books are.

slides.text: Write the dedication: 'Authors dedicate their books to people who inspired them. Who helped you become a writer this year? A parent who read with you? A grandparent who told you stories? Write: This book is dedicated to ___ because ___.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to make a dedication page, which is a super special way to thank someone. Think about who helped you this year with your writing – maybe someone who read to you a lot or told you exciting stories. You'll write "This book is dedicated to..." and tell them why they are so important to your writing journey.

slides.text: Design the covers: 'Your front cover needs a title, your name, and a beautiful illustration. Your back cover needs a blurb — a short paragraph that makes people want to read your portfolio. Think of it as an advertisement for your writing.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to design the outside of your portfolio to make it look super professional and exciting! For the front cover, you'll need a cool title for your whole collection of stories, your name as the author, a beautiful drawing, and the year. Then, for the back cover, you'll write a short, catchy description, like a movie trailer, to make people excited to read all your wonderful pieces inside.

slides.text: Assemble and present: 'Put everything in order: front cover, dedication, table of contents, writing pieces, author bio, back cover. Bind it together. Then present it proudly! Read your favorite piece aloud and sign the front page like a real author.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about putting your amazing book together in the perfect order: the front cover first, then the dedication page, the table of contents, all your fantastic writing pieces, your author biography, and finally the back cover. Then, you'll bind it all together and proudly present it to your family, read your very favorite story from the portfolio, and even sign it like a real author!

slides.prompt: Complete your portfolio: write the author biography with self-portrait, write the dedication page, design front and back covers, assemble everything in order, and bind it together. Then present the finished portfolio to your audience and read one piece aloud. Sign your portfolio!
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, it's time to finish your whole portfolio and share it with your family! Make sure your author biography and dedication page are perfect, design those awesome front and back covers, put all the pages in the right order, and bind it all together. Then, show off your masterpiece, read your best story, and sign your name like the brilliant author you are!

slides.text: Celebrate the author: 'You are holding YOUR book — filled with YOUR words, YOUR ideas, YOUR stories. From the dedication to the author biography, every page reflects who you are as a writer. This portfolio is a treasure. Keep writing all summer and beyond!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create professional book elements (cover, dedication, biography), assemble a cohesive portfolio, present their work with confidence, and demonstrate pride in their identity as a writer?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at that! You've created your very own published portfolio, filled with YOUR words and YOUR amazing ideas. You've shown everyone that you are a real writer by creating the cover, writing about yourself, dedicating your book, and sharing your stories. This portfolio is a treasure, and I know you'll keep writing wonderful things!

parent_notes: The portfolio celebration is a milestone moment. When a child holds their completed, bound portfolio, they experience authorship in a tangible way. The biography and dedication pages develop self-awareness and gratitude. The signing event adds playful formality that children adore. Consider having the portfolio professionally bound or laminated at a copy shop — this small investment transforms it from a school project into a keepsake the child will treasure for decades. Read the portfolio yourself with genuine interest and leave written comments on sticky notes throughout: 'This made me laugh!' or 'What a beautiful description!' For summer, provide a new blank journal and encourage daily writing — even a few sentences. The child who identifies as a writer will write. The child who identifies as someone who does writing assignments will stop when school ends.

title: Multiplication and Division Tournament
description: Students participate in a friendly multiplication and division tournament featuring timed challenges, team problems, and real-world applications. They celebrate their mastery of these operations through competitive games that reinforce fluency and build mathematical confidence.
instructions:
1. 'Welcome to the Multiplication and Division Tournament! Show off the skills you have built all year!'
2. Round 1 — Times Table Speed Round: How many multiplication facts can you answer correctly in 2 minutes? Use flash cards or a fact sheet.
3. Round 2 — Division Derby: Solve 10 division problems as quickly and accurately as possible.
4. Round 3 — Word Problem Challenge: Solve 5 multiplication and division word problems involving real-world scenarios (sharing cookies, arranging chairs, buying supplies).
5. Round 4 — Fact Family Relay: Given a product (e.g., 24), list ALL the factor pairs.
6. Round 5 — Create-a-Problem: Write your own multiplication and division word problems for a partner or parent to solve.
7. Score each round and calculate the total.
8. Award ceremony: celebrate strengths and growth.
9. 'Multiplication and division are yours forever!'
materials_needed: Multiplication flash cards or fact sheet

slides.heading: Math Tournament
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the big opening ceremony for our special math game! It's called the Multiplication and Division Championship, and it's a chance for you to show off all the super cool math skills you've learned this year. Get ready to have some fun and prove how awesome you are with numbers!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare materials for each round: flash cards for speed round, division problems at appropriate difficulty, word problems with real-world contexts, and a score sheet. Set up a tournament atmosphere.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the fun tools we need for our championship. We've got flashcards and fact sheets to practice our speedy multiplication, and special cards for division problems. There are also word problems that are like mini-mysteries to solve, plus scratch paper for your brilliant ideas, a timer to keep us on track, and a score sheet to record all your amazing wins. Don't forget to ask a grown-up to help you gather everything so we're all set for the games!

slides.text: Open the tournament: 'Welcome, mathematician, to the Multiplication and Division Championship! You will compete in 5 rounds, each testing different skills. This is a celebration of how far you have come. Ready? Let the tournament begin!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our official welcome to the tournament! Think of it like the starting whistle for a big race. We're going to go through five exciting rounds that will test different math powers you have. This whole thing is to celebrate how much you've learned, so take a deep breath, get excited, and let the championship begin!

slides.text: Rounds 1 and 2: 'Speed Round: answer as many multiplication facts as you can in 2 minutes. Division Derby: solve 10 division problems as quickly and accurately as possible. Show your work and check with the calculator when finished.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're diving into the first two exciting rounds! First is the Speed Round where you'll try to answer as many multiplication facts as you can in just two minutes – zoom! Then comes the Division Derby, where you'll solve 10 division problems super fast and accurately. Remember to write down your work so you can check it later with the calculator, just like a real math detective!

slides.text: Rounds 3 and 4: 'Word Problem Challenge: read carefully, identify the operation, solve, and check. Fact Family Relay: I give you a number like 24 — you find ALL the ways to multiply two numbers to get 24. How many can you find?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for rounds three and four, where things get really interesting! In the Word Problem Challenge, you'll read stories and figure out if you need to multiply or divide to find the answer – like sharing cookies or setting up chairs. Then, in the Fact Family Relay, I'll give you a number, and you have to find all the pairs of numbers that multiply together to make it. It's like finding secret number families!

slides.text: Round 5 — Create-a-Problem: 'Now YOU write the problems! Create 2 multiplication and 2 division word problems. Make them challenging but solvable. Then give them to a family member to solve. You become the teacher!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your chance to be the teacher! For Round 5, you get to create your very own multiplication and division word problems. Make them tricky and fun, maybe about your favorite toys or snacks, and then have a family member try to solve them. You'll see how good you are at making math challenges!

slides.prompt: Complete all 5 tournament rounds: Times Table Speed (2-minute challenge), Division Derby (10 problems), Word Problem Challenge (5 problems), Fact Family Relay (find all factor pairs for 3 numbers), and Create-a-Problem (write 4 problems for someone else). Record scores for each round.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where all your hard work pays off! You need to go through all five rounds of the tournament: the speedy multiplication, the quick division, the clever word problems, finding the fact families, and creating your own problems. As you finish each round, make sure to write down your score. You've got this – show me what you've learned!

slides.text: Award ceremony: 'Tally your tournament score! Whether you aced every round or worked hard through tricky problems, you showed mathematical courage and skill. Multiplication and division are powerful tools — and they belong to YOU now. Congratulations, champion!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child recall multiplication facts with reasonable fluency, solve division problems accurately, apply operations to word problems, identify factor pairs, and create mathematically sound problems?
slides.mascot_explanation: Woohoo, you made it to the end of the championship! Now it's time for the award ceremony where we look at your total score. No matter how many you got right or if some were super tricky, you showed amazing bravery and smarts. You've mastered multiplication and division, and those skills are yours to keep forever. Congratulations, math champion!

parent_notes: The tournament format adds excitement to review without the stress of a traditional test. Each round assesses a different facet of multiplicative thinking: fluency, accuracy, application, number relationships, and creative problem-posing. The Create-a-Problem round is particularly valuable because writing math problems requires deeper understanding than solving them. If you notice specific gaps during the tournament, note them for summer practice. Multiplication fluency develops over time — some children need additional repetition into the summer. Flash card practice (5-10 minutes daily) or multiplication apps can maintain skills without feeling burdensome. The key message is celebration, not judgment: compare the child's current performance to where they started, not to an abstract standard.

title: History Oral Presentations — Sharing My Favorite Period
description: Students prepare and deliver a formal oral presentation about their favorite historical period. They research additional details, create a visual aid, and present with confidence, demonstrating deep knowledge gained throughout the year of historical study.
instructions:
1. 'Historians share their knowledge through lectures and presentations. Today YOU deliver a historian's presentation about your favorite period!'
2. Choose your favorite historical period from the year's studies.
3. Prepare the presentation:
   - Introduction: name the period, its dates, and its location.
   - Key facts: 5 important things about this civilization or era.
   - Key people: 1-2 important figures and their contributions.
   - Daily life: what was it like to live during this time?
   - Legacy: how does this period still influence us today?
4. Create a visual aid: a poster, map, or artifact to show during the presentation.
5. Practice the presentation (aim for 4-5 minutes).
6. Deliver the presentation with eye contact, clear speech, and enthusiasm.
7. Handle audience questions.
8. 'You are a historian. You KNOW this story. Share it with pride!'
materials_needed: Poster board or large paper for visual aid

slides.heading: My Favorite Period in History
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our big project! It tells us we're going to be like real historians and share what we know about our favorite time in history. Isn't it exciting to pretend we're experts and teach others?

slides.setup_instructions: Help the child select their favorite period and gather reference materials. Prepare poster board and art supplies for the visual aid. Set up note cards for the presentation outline. Arrange a presentation area with audience seating.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our presentation. We've got reference materials, like books or websites, to help us find facts. A poster board and art supplies are for making a cool visual to show everyone, and note cards will help us remember what to say. We'll also need a timer to make sure we talk for just the right amount of time, and our family will be our audience!

slides.text: Choose and research: 'Which period of history captured your imagination most this year? Ancient Egypt? Greece? The Renaissance? The Space Age? Choose the one you feel most passionate about and gather your notes and references.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to pick our favorite historical time period! Think back to all the amazing places and people we learned about this year – maybe ancient Egypt with its pyramids, or knights and castles! Which one made you say "Wow!" the most? That's the one you should choose to become an expert on.

slides.text: Structure the presentation: 'Great presentations have a clear structure. Start with an introduction: name the period, when and where it happened. Then cover key facts, important people, daily life, and the period's lasting legacy. End with why YOU find it fascinating.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about organizing your thoughts, just like a detective plans their investigation. You'll start by telling us the name of your period, when and where it happened, then share five interesting facts, mention one or two super important people and what they did, describe what life was like back then, and finally, tell us how that time still affects us today.

slides.text: Create a visual aid: 'Make a poster, map, or diagram that illustrates your period. It could be a map of the empire, a drawing of daily life, or a chart of important events. Visual aids help your audience understand and remember your presentation.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to be an artist and a historian at the same time! You're going to make a visual aid, like a poster or a map, that shows something important about your chosen time period. This will help everyone else see what you're talking about and make your presentation even more awesome.

slides.text: Practice and present: 'Run through your presentation at least twice. Time yourself for 4-5 minutes. Use note cards as reminders but try to speak naturally, not read. Make eye contact. Show enthusiasm — if YOU are excited about the topic, your audience will be too!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to practice being a super star presenter! You'll go through your whole talk a couple of times to make sure it flows well and lasts about 4 or 5 minutes. Try to look at your audience, speak clearly, and show how excited you are – when you're enthusiastic, everyone else will be too!

slides.prompt: Prepare your historian's presentation: research your chosen period, write notes covering introduction, key facts, important people, daily life, and legacy. Create a visual aid. Practice twice. Then deliver the 4-5 minute presentation to your audience and answer questions.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the big moment where you become the historian! You'll do your whole presentation, showing off your visual aid and sharing all the cool things you learned. After you're done, your audience might ask you some questions, and since you're the expert, you'll know the answers!

slides.text: Celebrate the historian: 'You just delivered a real historical presentation. You researched, organized, created visuals, and spoke with authority about a period you care deeply about. THIS is what historians do — they study the past and share its lessons with the world. You are a historian.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child deliver a structured, informative oral presentation about a historical period, use visual aids effectively, speak with confidence and authority, and answer audience questions from their knowledge base?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You just gave a real historical presentation, just like the experts do! You researched, you made something to show, and you spoke with confidence about a time period you love. You absolutely nailed it and are officially a historian!

parent_notes: The oral history presentation is one of the most cognitively demanding tasks a young learner can do: it requires knowledge recall, organization, visual design, public speaking, and real-time thinking (during questions). The choice of favorite period is revealing — it shows which historical stories resonated most deeply. Ask genuine questions during the Q&A: How do you think people felt? What surprised you most? How is this period connected to other periods we studied? These questions push the child to think beyond memorized facts into analysis and interpretation. For summer, history lives in museums, historical sites, documentaries, and historical fiction. Visit a local museum or historical site and let the child be the guide — they know more than you might expect.

title: My World Atlas — Final Assembly and Presentation
description: Students complete the assembly of their personal World Atlas, adding a glossary of geographic terms, a final reflection page, and binding the atlas for permanent display. They present the finished atlas to family, demonstrating comprehensive geographic knowledge.
instructions:
1. 'Today your World Atlas becomes a finished book — a real reference guide you created with your own hands and knowledge!'
2. Create a glossary page with at least 15 geographic terms and definitions (continent, ocean, latitude, longitude, equator, hemisphere, peninsula, island, volcano, glacier, etc.).
3. Write a final reflection page: 'What I Learned About the World This Year' — 5-7 sentences about your geographic journey.
4. Check the table of contents: are all pages accounted for and numbered correctly?
5. Bind the atlas: use a binder, staples, ribbon binding, or have it professionally bound.
6. Present the finished atlas to family:
   - Show the cover and table of contents.
   - Open to your favorite map and explain it.
   - Show the special feature pages.
   - Read your reflection page aloud.
7. Display the atlas on a bookshelf alongside real atlases.
8. 'You are a cartographer and a geographer!'
materials_needed: Atlas binder with all maps and pages
Blank paper for glossary and reflection
Binding materials (stapler, ribbon, or binder rings)

slides.heading: My Finished World Atlas
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This slide is showing us the very last step of our amazing project: your finished World Atlas! It’s like your very own book filled with everything you’ve learned about our planet, and it’s ready to be shown off.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the atlas with all maps and special pages ready. Prepare a geographic terms reference list for the glossary. Have binding materials ready. Arrange a presentation space.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is the "getting ready" slide! You'll need your whole atlas book, some blank paper for extra pages, a list of geographic words to help you, and some special things for putting your book together like glue or ribbon. You'll also need your pencils and some family members to show it to, plus a spot on a bookshelf. Make sure you have your atlas all put together with your maps and special pages ready to go!

slides.text: Create the glossary: 'Every great atlas has a glossary — a list of important geographic terms and their definitions. Write at least 15 terms you have learned this year: continent, ocean, latitude, longitude, equator, hemisphere, peninsula, island, and more.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about making a super helpful part of your atlas called a glossary. Think of it like a dictionary for your book, where you'll write down at least 15 important geography words you learned, like "continent" or "ocean," and what they mean. This will help anyone reading your atlas understand all the cool places and features you've written about!

slides.text: Write your reflection: 'On a fresh page, write What I Learned About the World This Year. Share 5-7 sentences about your geographic journey: your favorite place, what surprised you, what skills you developed, and what you want to explore next.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to share your thoughts! On a new page, you're going to write about your journey exploring the world this year. What was your favorite place you learned about? What surprised you the most? You'll write about 5 to 7 sentences to tell your own story of becoming a geography whiz!

slides.text: Final assembly: 'Check the table of contents — is every page listed with the correct page number? Are all pages in order? Does the atlas flow logically from world overview to continents to special features? Make any final adjustments.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like a final check-up for your atlas book. You need to look at your table of contents, which is like the list at the beginning of a book, and make sure every single page is listed there with the right number. Also, check that all your pages are in the right order so your atlas makes sense when someone reads it.

slides.text: Bind and present: 'Bind your atlas securely. Then present it to your family like a published author at a book launch. Show the highlights, explain your favorite maps, read your reflection, and place it on the bookshelf next to real atlases.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for the big moment – presenting your masterpiece! You'll carefully put your atlas together so it's all neat and tidy. Then, imagine you're a famous author showing off their new book to your family! Show them the cover, your favorite maps, read your reflection, and then find a special spot on a bookshelf for it.

slides.prompt: Complete your atlas: write a glossary of 15+ geographic terms, write your reflection page, verify the table of contents, bind the atlas, and present it to your family. Show your favorite maps, explain the special features, and read your reflection aloud.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the exciting part where you get to put everything together! You'll finish writing your glossary and your reflection, double-check that all your pages are in order, and then bind your atlas so it looks like a real book. After that, you'll show it all to your family, sharing your favorite maps and reading what you wrote.

slides.text: Place it on the shelf: 'Your World Atlas sits on the bookshelf beside atlases made by professional cartographers. But YOUR atlas is unique — it contains your drawings, your knowledge, your voice, and your dreams. No other atlas in the world is quite like this one. You are a geographer and a cartographer!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define key geographic terms, reflect meaningfully on their learning journey, present a comprehensive geographic reference work, and demonstrate pride in their cartographic achievements?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at that! Your very own atlas is now sitting on a shelf, just like the ones made by grown-up map experts. But yours is extra special because it has all *your* drawings, *your* words, and all the amazing things *you* learned. You did it – you're a real geographer and cartographer!

parent_notes: The finished atlas is one of the most impressive artifacts of the year. It represents months of geographic learning compiled into a single, tangible reference work. The glossary develops precision in geographic vocabulary. The reflection page builds metacognitive skills. The presentation celebrates achievement. Consider having the atlas professionally bound at a copy shop — the cost is minimal and the result is a keepsake the child will treasure. Place it on a real bookshelf alongside published atlases to validate its significance. For summer, the atlas can travel with the family: bring it on trips, compare real landscapes to maps, and add new pages from vacation destinations. Geography comes alive through travel, even local day trips to different geographic features — rivers, hills, coastlines, or different neighborhoods.

title: Read-Aloud: The BFG by Roald Dahl — Chapters 13-19
description: Students continue The BFG as Sophie and the giant devise a plan to stop the man-eating giants by enlisting the Queen of England. They explore themes of courage, cleverness, and using one's unique strengths to solve problems bigger than oneself.
instructions:
1. Recap chapters 6-12: 'What have we learned about the BFG's world? What are the dangers? What is Sophie's plan?'
2. Read chapters 13-19 aloud with dramatic voices.
3. Pause at chapter 14 when Sophie and the BFG visit the Queen: 'Would YOU have the courage to ask a queen for help?'
4. Discuss the plan: 'Why is the BFG's dream-catching ability the KEY to the plan? How do they use his unique strength?'
5. Note how Sophie and the BFG work together: 'Neither one could do this alone. What does each one contribute?'
6. After chapter 17, discuss the giant capture: 'Was it satisfying to see the bullying giants caught? Why?'
7. Collect more Dahl invented words and add to the running list.
8. Predict the ending: 'How do you think the story will conclude?'
9. Journal response: Write about a time you and a friend worked together to solve a problem neither could solve alone.
materials_needed: Invented words list from previous sessions

slides.heading: The BFG Continues
slides.subheading: The Plan to Save the Children
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us the title of our next adventure in The BFG! It tells us that Sophie and the BFG are going to come up with a super smart plan to save all the children from the mean giants. Get ready for some exciting stuff!

slides.setup_instructions: Review the invented words list from previous sessions. Have the reading journal ready. Bookmark chapters 13-19.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for this part of the story. We need the book, *The BFG*, to read from, our special reading journal where we write our thoughts, a pencil for writing, the list of funny giant words we've collected, and a bookmark to keep our place for chapters 13 through 19. Make sure you have all these things handy before we start reading!

slides.text: Recap and build excitement: 'Sophie and the BFG have a problem: the other giants eat children every night. They need help from someone powerful enough to stop them. Their plan is brilliant — and it involves the Queen of England! Let us find out what happens.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like a little movie trailer for what's about to happen! It reminds us that the bad giants eat children, and Sophie and the BFG need a really clever plan to stop them. They're going to ask the Queen of England for help – wow, imagine meeting a queen! Let's find out if her help works.

slides.text: Read with full drama: 'These chapters have everything — sneaking into Buckingham Palace, meeting the Queen, military helicopters, and giant captures! Use different voices for Sophie, the BFG, the Queen, and the soldiers. Build the tension during the capture scene.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the really fun part – reading! We're going to pretend we're actors and read these chapters with all sorts of exciting voices. Use a big, deep voice for the BFG, a small voice for Sophie, maybe a fancy voice for the Queen, and even loud voices for the mean giants. Make sure to sound super excited and a little bit scared when they sneak around and capture the bad guys!

slides.text: Discuss teamwork: 'Sophie has the idea and the courage to approach the Queen. The BFG has the dream-catching skill to make the Queen believe them. Together they accomplish what neither could do alone. Why is teamwork so powerful?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is all about how Sophie and the BFG are like a super team! Sophie is super brave and comes up with the ideas, while the BFG has his special dream-catching skills that help the Queen believe them. It shows us that when you work together with a friend, you can do amazing things that you couldn't do all by yourself.

slides.text: Discuss justice: 'The man-eating giants have terrorized children for centuries. Now they face consequences. How do you feel about their capture? Is the punishment fair? What does this story say about standing up to bullies?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Think about those big, mean giants who were always scaring everyone. Now they're finally getting caught! Does it feel good to see them get in trouble? This part makes us think about why it's important to stand up to people who are being mean, just like Sophie and the BFG did.

slides.prompt: In your reading journal, write about a time you worked with a friend or family member to solve a problem neither of you could solve alone. What did each person contribute? How did working together make you stronger? How is this like Sophie and the BFG's partnership?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a super storyteller! In your reading journal, write about a time you and a friend or family member worked together to fix a problem. What did you do, and what did your helper do? Think about how working together made it easier, just like Sophie and the BFG!

slides.text: Reflect: 'Sophie is small, the BFG is gentle, and together they defeated the biggest bullies in the world. This story teaches us that courage, cleverness, and teamwork can overcome even the most frightening challenges. We will finish the story next time!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child analyze character partnerships and teamwork dynamics, identify how unique strengths contribute to problem-solving, discuss themes of justice and courage, and make text-to-life connections about collaboration?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we made it to the end of this part of the story! Sophie and the BFG, even though they are small and gentle, showed us that being brave and working together can beat even the biggest bullies. It’s pretty amazing how they solved such a huge problem, and we'll find out the rest of the story next time!

parent_notes: These chapters are the action climax of the story and children typically listen with rapt attention. The theme of teamwork is especially relevant: Sophie contributes courage and ideas, the BFG contributes his unique abilities, and together they achieve what neither could alone. This is a powerful message for children who sometimes feel too small to make a difference. The justice theme — bullies facing consequences — satisfies children's deep sense of fairness. The journal prompt about personal teamwork connects fiction to real experience. For summer reading, continue with Dahl's other books: Matilda, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Danny the Champion of the World. Dahl's books consistently feature small, clever children who outsmart powerful adults — a theme that resonates deeply with elementary-age readers.

title: Letter to My Future Self — A Time Capsule in Words
description: Students write a letter to their future selves, to be opened at the end of next school year. They describe their current life, interests, achievements, hopes, and advice, creating a powerful time capsule document that captures who they are right now.
instructions:
1. 'Imagine opening a letter one year from now — written by YOU, today. What would you want to tell your future self?'
2. Date the letter: today's date.
3. Describe your current life:
   - How old are you? What grade are you in?
   - What are your favorite things to do?
   - Who are your best friends?
   - What is your favorite book, movie, food?
4. Share your proudest achievement from this school year.
5. Describe something you are working on or struggling with.
6. Write advice to your future self: 'Remember to...' or 'Do not forget...'
7. Set 3 goals for the coming year.
8. Write hopes and dreams: 'I hope that by the time you read this...'
9. Sign and seal the letter in an envelope labeled: 'DO NOT OPEN UNTIL [date one year from now]'
10. Store it in a safe place.

slides.heading: Letter to My Future Self
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing you the title of our special project: "Letter to My Future Self," and it tells us it's like making a "Time Capsule in Words." It's a way to send a message to yourself from the past!

slides.setup_instructions: Provide nice paper for the letter. Have an envelope ready with a label that reads: DO NOT OPEN UNTIL [date one year from now]. Identify a safe storage location.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are the things we need for our time capsule letter! We'll need some nice paper and a pencil to write, an envelope to put our letter in, and a special sticker to seal it shut. We also need to find a safe spot to keep it so it won't get lost before next year.

slides.text: Set the scene: 'Imagine it is exactly one year from today. You are one year older, one year wiser, and one year further on your journey. You open this envelope and find a letter from your PAST self — the YOU who exists right now. What do you want to say?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine you're opening a secret package one whole year from now, and guess what? It's a letter from YOU, but the YOU from today! This first step is thinking about what your past self would want to share with your older, wiser future self.

slides.text: Describe the present: 'Start by capturing who you are RIGHT NOW. How old are you? What grade? What do you love? Who are your friends? What makes you laugh? What is your favorite everything? These details will be fascinating to read next year.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we need to tell your future self all about who you are right this very second! Think about how old you are, what grade you're in, all the things you love doing, your best friends, and your favorite things like books or snacks. It's like a snapshot of your life today!

slides.text: Share achievements and struggles: 'Tell your future self what you are proudest of this year. Also share something you are working on — a skill you are building, a challenge you are facing. Your future self will be amazed at how much you have grown.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is super important for your future self to see how much you've grown. What's something you did this year that made you feel really proud? Also, think about something tricky you're working on, like learning a new skill or figuring something out.

slides.text: Look forward: 'Write advice to your future self: Remember to be brave. Do not forget to be kind. Set 3 goals for the coming year. Write your hopes and dreams. Then sign it, seal it, and store it. You have just created a time capsule.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to give your future self some good advice! What reminders would be helpful for you next year, like "Remember to be kind" or "Don't forget to try new things"? Then, you'll pick three things you want to accomplish in the next year and share your big hopes and dreams.

slides.prompt: Write a letter to your future self (at least one full page). Include: today's date, description of your current life and interests, proudest achievement, a current challenge, advice, 3 goals for next year, and your hopes and dreams. Seal it in an envelope labeled with the opening date.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the big writing part! You'll write your whole letter, putting in today's date, describing yourself now, sharing your proudest moment and something you're working on, giving advice, and listing your goals and dreams. Then, carefully fold it, put it in the envelope, and seal it with that special sticker.

slides.text: Seal the time capsule: 'This letter holds a snapshot of who you are at this moment. One year from now, you will open it and be amazed — at how much you remember, how much you have changed, and how much you have grown. Guard this letter carefully. It is a gift from present-you to future-you.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write a reflective, detailed personal letter, describe their current life with specificity, set meaningful goals, and express hopes and dreams in writing?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You've sealed up your very own time capsule letter. It's like a special gift from you today to you next year, showing how awesome you are right now and how much you'll change. Keep it safe in that special spot you picked!

parent_notes: The letter to the future self is one of the most meaningful writing exercises a child can do. It develops self-awareness, goal-setting, and temporal thinking — the ability to imagine oneself in the future. Store the letter somewhere safe and set a calendar reminder to open it one year from today. When the child reads it next year, the experience is invariably powerful: they see how much they have changed, which goals they achieved, and what stayed the same. This practice builds the habit of reflection and self-assessment that serves people throughout their lives. Consider making this an annual tradition. Some families create a time capsule box that grows each year. The accumulating letters become a treasured personal history.

title: Geometry and Measurement Scavenger Hunt
description: Students go on a geometry and measurement scavenger hunt through their home and yard, identifying geometric shapes, measuring objects, calculating perimeters and areas, and documenting their findings. They apply classroom geometry to the real world.
instructions:
1. 'Geometry is EVERYWHERE — in buildings, furniture, nature, and art. Today we go on a scavenger hunt to find it!'
2. Geometry Hunt List:
   - Find 3 circles, 3 triangles, 3 rectangles, and 3 squares in your environment.
   - Find 1 sphere, 1 cylinder, 1 cone, and 1 rectangular prism.
   - Measure the length and width of 3 rooms.
   - Calculate the perimeter of 2 rectangular objects.
   - Estimate, then measure, 5 objects in inches and centimeters.
   - Find examples of symmetry in nature.
3. Document each finding: sketch it, name the shape, and record measurements.
4. Calculate the area of your bedroom (length x width).
5. Find the most interesting geometric shape in your environment.
6. Create a 'Geometry Found!' poster with your best findings.
7. 'Math is not just in your workbook — it is in your WORLD!'

slides.heading: Geometry Scavenger Hunt
slides.mascot_explanation: Hey there! This first slide is like the title page for our super fun adventure today. It's called the "Geometry Scavenger Hunt," and it tells us that math, especially shapes, isn't just in our math books – it's all around us in the real world! Get ready to become a geometry detective!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare the scavenger hunt checklist. Ensure the child has a tape measure or long ruler, clipboard, and pencil. Identify safe areas for the hunt (inside the home and yard).
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll need for our hunt. We've got our scavenger hunt list to keep track, a tape measure or ruler to measure things, a clipboard and pencil for drawing and writing, and even a camera if you want to take pictures of your amazing finds! There's also poster paper and colored pencils for when we make our awesome "Geometry Found!" poster later. Make sure you have all these things ready, maybe ask a grown-up to help you gather them.

slides.text: Launch the hunt: 'Geometry is hiding everywhere — in the shape of windows, the pattern on a rug, the curve of a bowl, the angles of a roof. Your mission: find and document as many geometric shapes as possible in your environment!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the real fun begins! Our mission is to explore our house and yard and find shapes hiding everywhere. Think about the shapes of things you see every day, like the windows in your house or even the pattern on your rug. Your job is to be a super spotter and find as many different shapes as you can!

slides.text: 2D shapes: 'Find 3 circles, 3 triangles, 3 rectangles, and 3 squares. Sketch each one, name it, and write where you found it. Look up, down, and all around — geometry is in places you might not expect!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to look for flat shapes, like shapes you can draw on paper. We need to find three circles, three triangles, three rectangles, and three squares. As you find each one, draw a picture of it, write down what shape it is, and tell us where you found it, like "a square on the door." Keep your eyes peeled everywhere!

slides.text: 3D shapes and measurements: 'Now find 3D shapes: a ball (sphere), a can (cylinder), an ice cream cone shape (cone), and a box (rectangular prism). Then get your measuring tape and measure 3 rooms: length and width. Calculate the perimeter: add all four sides.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is about shapes that have depth, like real objects you can hold! We need to find a ball (that's a sphere!), a can (that's a cylinder!), something that looks like an ice cream cone (that's a cone!), and a box (that's a rectangular prism!). After that, we'll use our tape measure to find out how long and wide three different rooms are, and then we'll add up all the sides of two rectangular things to find their perimeter.

slides.text: Create your poster: 'Make a Geometry Found poster showing your best discoveries. Include sketches, measurements, shape names, and a calculation of your bedroom's area (length times width). This poster proves that math lives everywhere!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to show off your amazing discoveries! We're going to make a "Geometry Found!" poster using the poster paper and colored pencils. You can draw your favorite shapes, write down the measurements you took, and even show how you figured out the area of your bedroom by multiplying its length and width. This poster will be proof that math is all over the place!

slides.prompt: Complete the scavenger hunt: find and document 12+ 2D shapes, 4+ 3D shapes, measure 3 rooms, calculate 2 perimeters, estimate and measure 5 objects, find symmetry in nature, and calculate your bedroom's area. Create a poster showcasing your best geometric discoveries.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we're going to do on our scavenger hunt! We'll find lots of flat shapes and solid shapes, measure rooms and other objects, figure out perimeters and areas, and even look for cool patterns in nature. Then, we'll put our best findings on a poster to show everyone how much geometry is in our world. You've got this – let's get started!

slides.text: Celebrate the discoveries: 'You found geometry everywhere! Circles in clocks, rectangles in windows, triangles in roofs, spheres in fruit, cylinders in cans. Mathematics is not something that only exists in books — it is the language of the world around you. Keep looking!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify 2D and 3D shapes in the environment, measure objects accurately with standard tools, calculate perimeter and area, and connect geometric concepts to real-world contexts?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You went on a super geometry scavenger hunt and found shapes everywhere, from circles on clocks to rectangles in windows! It's so cool that math isn't just in books, but it's the secret code of the world around us. Keep looking for those shapes, you're a fantastic geometry detective!

parent_notes: The geometry scavenger hunt transforms abstract concepts into concrete, visible realities. Children who discover geometry in their environment develop spatial awareness that benefits them in mathematics, science, art, and everyday life. The measurement component reinforces practical skills with standard tools. Area calculation connects multiplication to real-world applications. For summer, keep geometry alive: point out shapes in architecture during walks, discuss symmetry in nature, and play tangram puzzles. Construction projects (even simple ones like building a birdhouse) require measurement, angles, and spatial reasoning. The goal is for the child to see the world through mathematical eyes — noticing patterns, shapes, and relationships everywhere they look.

title: Design Your Own Experiment — The Scientific Method Mastery
description: Students design and conduct their own original experiment from scratch, applying every step of the scientific method they have learned this year. They choose a question, form a hypothesis, design a procedure, collect data, and draw conclusions independently.
instructions:
1. 'You have done dozens of experiments this year. Now it is time for the ULTIMATE challenge: design your OWN experiment from scratch!'
2. Choose a question to investigate. Brainstorm options:
   - Does music affect how fast you complete a puzzle?
   - Which material keeps ice frozen longest: foil, cloth, or plastic?
   - Do plants grow faster in light or dark?
   - Does the height of a ramp affect how far a ball rolls?
3. Write a clear hypothesis: 'I think ___ because ___'
4. Design the procedure: What materials do you need? What steps will you follow? What will you measure?
5. Identify variables: What are you changing? What are you keeping the same? What are you measuring?
6. Conduct the experiment carefully.
7. Record data in a chart or table.
8. Draw conclusions: Was your hypothesis correct? What did you learn?
9. Write a complete experiment report.

slides.heading: Design Your Own Experiment
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the grand opening of our big science adventure! It's showing us that today, we get to be the boss of our own experiment, using all the cool science steps we've learned this year. Think of it like being a detective, but instead of solving a mystery, we're finding out new things about the world!

slides.setup_instructions: Help the child brainstorm experiment ideas and gather necessary materials. Prepare a data chart template. Have the science journal ready for the full experiment report.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows all the tools we'll need for our super-science mission. We have our science journal to write everything down, experiment materials which will be different for each of us, a timer to keep track of how long things take, measuring tools to get exact numbers, a data chart to organize our findings, and a pencil to do all our writing. You'll need to ask a grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: Choose your question: 'What do you want to find out? Good science questions start with: Does, How, Which, or What happens when. Pick something you are genuinely curious about — the best experiments come from real curiosity.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our first big step: asking a question! See how good science questions start with words like 'Does,' 'How,' 'Which,' or 'What happens when'? We need to think about something we're really, really curious about, like maybe if a certain toy works better in the sun or shade. What's something you've always wondered about?

slides.text: Hypothesis and design: 'Write your prediction: I think ___ because ___. Then plan your experiment: What materials do you need? What exact steps will you follow? What will you change (variable) and what will you keep the same (controls)?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super smart part: making a prediction, called a hypothesis! You'll write down what you *think* will happen and *why* you think that, like "I think the red crayon will draw darker because it looks brighter." Then, you'll plan out exactly how you'll test it, telling us what stuff you need and what steps you'll follow, and what you'll change on purpose.

slides.text: Conduct and record: 'Follow your procedure carefully. Record EVERYTHING: measurements, observations, times, and any surprises. Use a data chart to organize your numbers. Take photos if you can. Good scientists document everything.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about doing the experiment! You'll carefully follow the steps you wrote down earlier, and it's super important to write down *everything* you see, like how long something took or how big it got. Using your data chart will help keep all your numbers neat and tidy, and taking pictures is like making a memory of your science discovery!

slides.text: Conclude and report: 'Look at your data. Was your hypothesis correct? If not, that is perfectly fine — many great discoveries came from wrong hypotheses! Write your conclusion: what you found out, what surprised you, and what you would do differently next time.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to be a science detective and figure out what your experiment told you! Look at all the numbers and notes you wrote down. Was your first guess, your hypothesis, right? It's totally okay if it wasn't, because even when things don't go as planned, scientists learn something new and amazing!

slides.prompt: Design and conduct your own experiment: write a question, form a hypothesis, list materials, write a procedure, identify variables, conduct the experiment, record data in a chart, and write a conclusion. Complete a full experiment report in your science journal.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to put everything together and show off your awesome work! You'll write down your question, your guess, what materials you used, your steps, what you changed, what you measured, all your results from the experiment, and what you learned in the end. It's like writing the story of your own scientific discovery!

slides.text: Celebrate the scientist: 'You just did what real scientists do every day: asked a question, made a prediction, designed an experiment, collected data, and drew conclusions. The scientific method is yours now — a tool for understanding ANYTHING you are curious about. Use it all summer and for the rest of your life!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently design a controlled experiment, form a testable hypothesis, identify variables, collect and organize data, and draw evidence-based conclusions?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You just completed your very own experiment from start to finish, just like a real scientist. You asked a question, made a guess, tested it out, and figured out what happened – that's the scientific method, and now you know how to use it to learn about anything you want!

parent_notes: Designing an original experiment is the culmination of a year of scientific learning. It requires the child to apply every component of the scientific method independently. The key is to let the child choose a question they genuinely care about — intrinsic motivation drives better science. Resist the urge to over-direct; if the experimental design is imperfect, that is okay — learning to improve methodology is part of the process. If the hypothesis is wrong, celebrate the discovery: science advances more through unexpected results than expected ones. For summer, encourage the child to conduct experiments regularly. Kitchen science, outdoor investigations, and simple physics experiments keep scientific thinking alive. The child who asks Why? and then designs a way to find out is developing one of the most powerful thinking habits possible.

title: Art and Music Portfolio Assembly — My Creative Year
description: Students assemble a comprehensive art and music portfolio documenting their creative journey throughout the year. They select representative pieces, write reflections on their artistic growth, and create a visual record of skills developed across multiple media.
instructions:
1. 'Today we create a record of your entire creative journey — every art technique, every song learned, every creative breakthrough.'
2. Gather all remaining artwork not selected for the art show.
3. Create a 'Creative Journey' booklet:
   - Page 1: Title page — 'My Creative Year by [Name]'
   - Page 2: Art techniques I learned (list with small sketches)
   - Page 3: Songs I can play on the recorder (list with difficulty ratings)
   - Page 4: My artistic growth — compare an early piece to a recent one
   - Page 5: My favorite art medium and why
   - Page 6: Musicians and artists who inspired me
   - Page 7: Goals for next year's creative work
4. Photograph artwork that cannot fit in the booklet.
5. Record yourself playing one recorder piece (audio or video).
6. 'Your creativity has grown in ways you might not even realize!'
materials_needed: Glue for mounting small art samples

slides.heading: My Creative Portfolio
slides.subheading: Documenting a Year of Art and Music
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover page for our special project! It's called "My Creative Portfolio," and it's going to show everyone all the amazing art and music you've made this whole year. Think of it like a treasure box for all your cool creations!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a blank booklet by stapling pages together. Gather all artwork. Have the recorder and songbook ready. Prepare a camera or phone for documentation.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this project, we need a few things to make our portfolio sparkle. We'll need all the artwork you've made, your recorder and the music sheets, a blank booklet for writing, some colored pencils and markers to decorate, and a camera or phone to take pictures. You'll also need a pencil and some glue, and don't forget to have your booklet pages ready by stapling them together!

slides.text: Review your creative year: 'Look at all the art you have made and all the songs you have learned. You have worked with pencils, paint, clay, collage, and more. You have played dozens of songs on the recorder. That is an incredible body of creative work!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about remembering how much you've learned! Look back at all the fantastic art you've created and every song you've mastered on the recorder. You've tried so many different ways to make art, like drawing, painting, and even using clay, and you've played tons of songs! It's proof of how much your creativity has grown.

slides.text: Create the booklet: 'Your Creative Journey booklet tells the story of your artistic growth. Start with the title page. Then list every art technique you learned with a small sketch example of each. List every recorder song with a difficulty rating.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to build our "Creative Journey" booklet! The first page is the title page, where you'll write your name. Then, for the next pages, you'll list all the art tricks you learned, maybe with a little picture to show each one, and list all the songs you can play on the recorder, rating how tricky they are.

slides.text: Show your growth: 'Find your earliest artwork and your most recent. Put them side by side. What differences do you see? More detail? Better proportion? Stronger color? Write about how your artistic skills have changed.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This page is where we see how much you've improved! Find one of your very first pieces of art and then find one you made recently. Put them next to each other and see what's different – maybe your drawings have more details now, or your colors are brighter! Write down what you notice about how your art skills have gotten better.

slides.text: Look forward: 'Write about your favorite art medium and why you love it. List artists or musicians who inspired you. Then set creative goals for next year: a new technique to try, a new instrument, or a big project you want to tackle.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we get to think about what you love and what's next! Tell us about your favorite way to make art and why you like it so much. Think about any artists or musicians who made you feel inspired to create your own amazing work. Then, it's time to dream big and set some fun goals for all the cool art and music you want to make next year!

slides.prompt: Assemble your Creative Journey booklet with all 7 pages. Photograph artwork that does not fit. Record yourself playing your best recorder piece. Compare early and recent artwork and write about your growth. Set creative goals for next year.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we put it all together! You'll finish your "Creative Journey" booklet with all seven pages. If you have artwork that's too big for the booklet, we'll take a picture of it to include. Then, you'll record yourself playing your very best song on the recorder. Remember to look at your early and recent art and write about how you've grown, and don't forget to write down those exciting goals for next year!

slides.text: Celebrate creativity: 'Your Creative Journey booklet captures a year of artistic growth that you might otherwise forget. The techniques you learned, the songs you played, the growth you experienced — it is all documented here. Creativity is a skill that grows with practice. Keep creating all summer long!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child evaluate their own artistic growth, identify techniques and skills developed, articulate creative preferences, document musical progress, and set meaningful creative goals?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at everything you've accomplished! Your "Creative Journey" booklet is like a super cool diary that shows off all your amazing growth in art and music. You learned new skills, played new songs, and became an even better artist and musician. Keep practicing your creativity, and you can make even more wonderful things all summer long!

parent_notes: The creative portfolio validates art and music as serious domains of learning, not just fun extras. By documenting techniques learned, songs mastered, and growth observed, the child sees their creative development as a real achievement. The comparison of early and recent work is often the most powerful element — artistic growth is dramatic and visible. The recording of a recorder piece creates an audio keepsake. For summer, provide art supplies and encourage free creative expression without assignments or evaluation. Visit art museums, attend concerts, and expose the child to diverse creative traditions. The child who sees themselves as a creative person will continue creating. Art supplies, a sketchbook, and access to music make the perfect summer creative kit.

title: Reflection and Goal-Setting for Next Year
description: Students engage in a guided reflection on the entire school year, identifying accomplishments, challenges overcome, and skills developed. They set meaningful goals for the summer and the next school year, developing the metacognitive habit of self-assessment and forward planning.
instructions:
1. 'Before we look ahead, let us look back at the incredible year you have had.'
2. Create a 'My Year in Review' chart:
   - Things I learned to do this year (list at least 10)
   - Challenges I overcame
   - My proudest moment
   - Something that surprised me about myself
   - My favorite memory from this school year
3. Rate your growth in each subject on a scale of 1-5 stars.
4. Set summer goals (3-5):
   - One reading goal
   - One physical/outdoor goal
   - One creative goal
   - One personal growth goal
5. Set next year goals (3-5):
   - One academic goal
   - One social goal
   - One character goal
6. Write a personal motto or mantra for the summer.
7. Share your reflections and goals with a family member.
materials_needed: Year in Review template or large paper

slides.heading: Reflection and Goals
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the cover of a special book about YOU and your amazing school year! It's called "Reflection and Goals," which means we're going to think about all the cool things you did and then decide on some fun plans for the future. It's like looking back at your favorite toys from last year and then picking out new ones you want to play with!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a Year in Review template with sections for accomplishments, challenges, favorites, and growth ratings. Prepare a goal-setting worksheet for summer and next year. Create a calm, reflective atmosphere.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's get our supplies ready for this adventure! We've got our "Year in Review" paper, which is like a treasure map for all your accomplishments. Then we have colored pencils and markers to make it super colorful, and star stickers to show how much you've grown! Don't forget your goal worksheet, a pencil, and find a nice, quiet spot where you can really think. Ask a grown-up to help you gather everything!

slides.text: Look back with pride: 'This year you have accomplished more than you probably realize. Let us make a list of everything you learned to do. I will start: you learned to multiply! You read chapter books! Now you add to the list — aim for at least 10 things.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is all about celebrating how much you've learned and grown this year! Think about all the new things you can do now, like riding your bike without training wheels or learning a new song. Your teacher will even give you an example, like learning to multiply! Now it's your turn to write down at least 10 things you learned – big or small, it all counts!

slides.text: Acknowledge challenges: 'Growth comes from facing hard things. What was challenging this year? Maybe long division was tough at first. Maybe writing paragraphs felt overwhelming. You faced those challenges and came through. Write about the challenges you overcame.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to think about the times when things felt a little tricky, because that's how we get stronger! Remember when learning to tie your shoes seemed impossible, but you kept trying? That’s what this is about – thinking about those moments that were hard but you didn't give up. Write down a challenge or two that you faced and how you worked through it.

slides.text: Rate your growth: 'For each subject — language, math, science, history, geography, art, music, practical life — give yourself a star rating from 1 to 5. This is not about grades — it is about how much you GREW. Even 3 stars means solid growth!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we get to be like superheroes and rate our own superpowers – your skills in different subjects! For things like reading, math, or even art, you'll give yourself a star rating from 1 to 5. It's not about getting the best grade, but about how much you feel you learned and improved. Even a few stars show you've made awesome progress!

slides.text: Set goals: 'Now look forward. Set 3-5 goals for summer: What will you read? What will you do outside? What will you create? What personal quality will you develop? Then set 3-5 goals for next year. Write them clearly and specifically.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to dream big for the summer and next year! We'll think about fun things you want to do, like reading a cool new book or playing outside every day. Then, we’ll set goals for school too, like becoming even better at math or making new friends. Writing these down helps make them happen, like making a secret plan!

slides.prompt: Complete your Year in Review: list 10+ things you learned, describe challenges overcome, identify your proudest moment and favorite memory, rate growth in each subject, set 3-5 summer goals and 3-5 next year goals, and write a personal motto. Share everything with a family member.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you're doing so great! This is the big activity where you get to fill out your whole "Year in Review" and your goal sheets. Remember to list all those amazing things you learned, the challenges you conquered, your proudest moment, and your favorite memory. Then, fill in your star ratings, set your summer and next year goals, and even come up with a cool motto for the summer. After you're all done, share it with someone you love!

slides.text: Close with pride: 'You have just done something that most adults struggle with: honest self-reflection and intentional goal-setting. You know where you have been, what you have accomplished, and where you are headed. THAT is the mark of a mature, thoughtful learner. I am so proud of you.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child accurately identify personal achievements and growth, acknowledge and reflect on challenges, set specific and meaningful goals for the future, and articulate a personal vision for continued growth?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! Look at everything you've accomplished! You took the time to think about all the amazing things you did this year and made super smart plans for the future. That's a huge deal and shows you're a really thoughtful learner. Give yourself a big pat on the back – I'm so proud of how far you've come!

parent_notes: Self-reflection and goal-setting are among the most important life skills, yet they are rarely taught explicitly. This lesson makes them concrete and accessible. The child's self-ratings may differ from your assessment — that is fine. What matters is the practice of self-evaluation, not the accuracy of the ratings. When the child shares their reflections, listen without correcting. Add your own observations gently: 'I also noticed how much your reading improved!' The goals should be specific enough to be achievable: not 'read more' but 'read 10 books this summer.' Post the summer goals somewhere visible. Check in periodically without nagging. The personal motto gives the child a touchstone for difficult moments. For summer, model reflection yourself: share your own goals and what you learned this year alongside the child. Self-reflection is a family practice.

title: Poetry Slam — Performing Our Favorite Poems
description: Students select and perform their favorite poems from the year in a poetry slam format. They practice expressive reading, memorize short poems, and experience the joy of spoken word performance, celebrating language at its most beautiful and powerful.
instructions:
1. 'Poetry is meant to be heard! Today we host a poetry slam — a celebration of spoken poetry.'
2. Review all poems read and written during the year.
3. Select 3 poems to perform:
   - One poem you wrote yourself
   - One poem by a famous poet that you love
   - One poem that makes the audience laugh or feel something strong
4. For each poem, practice:
   - Memorize at least one short poem (8 lines or fewer)
   - Read the others with dramatic expression
   - Use pauses, volume changes, and gestures
5. Create a poetry slam program listing the poems and poets.
6. Perform for an audience:
   - Introduce each poem: title, poet, and why you chose it
   - Perform with maximum expression
   - Invite audience snaps or applause between poems
7. 'Poetry is language at its most powerful!'
materials_needed: Collection of poems from the year
Optional: microphone or cardboard tube as pretend microphone

slides.heading: Poetry Slam!
slides.subheading: Celebrating the Power of Spoken Word
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This slide is like the grand opening sign for our super fun event today: a Poetry Slam! It means we get to share poems out loud, and it’s all about how powerful words can be when we speak them from our hearts.

slides.setup_instructions: Collect all poems from the year (both student-written and published poems studied). Set up a performance space with a standing area and audience seating. Prepare a program template.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is our backstage area for the slam! We've got poems we wrote and poems we read, like little treasures. The poetry books are full of amazing words from other people. The program template is like a playbill for our show, and the performance space is where the magic will happen – you'll be the star! We even have a pretend microphone to make it feel extra special, and a timer to keep us on track.

slides.text: Select your poems: 'Look through all the poems from this year — the ones you wrote, the ones we read together, and any favorites from poetry books. Choose 3 that you want to perform: one you wrote, one by a famous poet, and one that creates a strong emotion.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we pick our star poems! Think about all the poems we've read and written this year. You need to choose three special ones: one that YOU created, one by a poet you really admire, and one that will make everyone feel super happy or excited or maybe even a little bit silly!

slides.text: Practice performing: 'Poetry performance is an art. Speak slowly, let the words breathe. Use pauses for dramatic effect. Change your volume — sometimes a whisper is more powerful than a shout. Use gestures that match the mood. Try to memorize at least one short poem.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make those poems come alive! When we read poetry out loud, we can change how fast we talk, pause to let words sink in, and even use our hands to show what the poem is about. Try to memorize one of the shorter poems so you can say it without reading, like a secret message!

slides.text: Create the program: 'Write a poetry slam program listing each poem, its author, and a brief note about why you chose it. This is what the audience will follow during your performance.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like making the menu for our poetry feast! You'll write down the name of each poem and who wrote it, and then add a little sentence about why you picked it. This helps your audience follow along and know what amazing words are coming their way.

slides.text: Perform: 'Step up to the mic! Introduce yourself as a poet. Before each poem, tell the audience the title and why you love it. Then perform with all your heart. Poetry slam audiences snap their fingers or clap after each poem — encourage your audience to participate!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for your big moment! When you step up, you'll tell everyone the title of your poem and why you chose it, like sharing a secret. Then, give it your all when you perform, using all those cool expression tricks we practiced. Remember to encourage your audience to show their love with snaps and applause!

slides.prompt: Select 3 poems (one original, one famous, one emotional). Practice performing each with expression, pauses, and gestures. Memorize at least one. Create a program. Deliver your poetry slam performance to your audience with introductions for each poem.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is it – showtime! You'll pick your three poems, practice making them sound amazing with your voice and actions, and memorize at least one. Then, you'll create your program and perform like a true poet, introducing each one. You’ve got this!

slides.text: Celebrate the poet: 'You stood up and shared the power of poetry with your voice, your expression, and your heart. Poetry has been part of human culture since the very beginning — from ancient chants to modern spoken word. You are now part of that tradition. Never stop reading and sharing poetry!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child select poems for an audience, perform with expressive reading techniques (pace, volume, gesture, pause), memorize and recite short poetry, and introduce literary works with personal context?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You shared your voice and made poetry come alive for everyone. Think about how amazing it is that words can make people feel so many things, just like the ancient storytellers. You're part of that amazing tradition now, so keep sharing those powerful words!

parent_notes: Poetry slams bring language to life in a way that silent reading cannot. The physical act of performing poetry — standing, projecting the voice, using gestures — engages multiple modalities and builds confidence. Performing their own poem alongside a famous poet's work validates the child's writing as worthy of the same stage. If the child is nervous, remind them that poetry slams are celebratory, not competitive. Snap your fingers enthusiastically (the traditional poetry slam response). Ask for an encore. For summer, explore poetry in everyday life: song lyrics are poetry set to music, rap is spoken word poetry, and nature inspires haiku. Keep a poetry collection accessible and read a poem aloud together occasionally. The child who loves poetry has a lifelong source of comfort, beauty, and self-expression.

title: Math Escape Room — Solving Puzzles to Save the Day
description: Students participate in a math escape room where they must solve a series of mathematical puzzles across all topics studied during the year to unlock the final code. They apply addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, fractions, geometry, and logic in a thrilling adventure format.
instructions:
1. 'Welcome to the Math Escape Room! You must solve 6 math puzzles to crack the final code and save the day!'
2. Set the story: 'A treasure chest is locked with a 6-digit code. Each puzzle gives you one digit.'
3. Puzzle 1 (Addition/Subtraction): Solve a chain of operations: 456 + 378 - 512 + 149 = ? The ones digit is code digit 1.
4. Puzzle 2 (Multiplication): A farmer has 7 rows of 8 apple trees. How many trees? The tens digit is code digit 2.
5. Puzzle 3 (Division): 156 cookies shared equally among 12 friends. How many each? Code digit 3.
6. Puzzle 4 (Fractions): What is 3/4 of 48? The tens digit is code digit 4.
7. Puzzle 5 (Geometry): A rectangle has length 9 and width 6. What is the perimeter? The tens digit is code digit 5.
8. Puzzle 6 (Logic): I am a number. Double me, add 10, and you get 36. What am I? Code digit 6.
9. Combine all digits to unlock the treasure chest.
10. Inside: a certificate or small treat!
materials_needed: Certificate or small treat as prize

slides.heading: Math Escape Room
slides.subheading: Crack the Code, Save the Day!
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for a super fun adventure! It's called the "Math Escape Room," and it means we get to use our math skills to solve puzzles and "save the day" by cracking a secret code. It's going to be exciting, like a treasure hunt but with numbers!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 6 envelopes, each containing a math puzzle. Create a code sheet with 6 blank spaces. Set up a lockbox or wrapped package as the treasure. Optional: set a 30-minute timer for added excitement.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, here are all the special things we need for our adventure. We have six puzzle envelopes, like little mystery boxes, a pencil and paper to write down our answers, a special code sheet to keep track of the secret numbers, and a lockbox or treasure that we're trying to open. We're also going to race against time, so get ready for some excitement!

slides.text: Set the scene: 'A treasure chest has been locked with a secret 6-digit code. The only way to crack the code is to solve 6 math puzzles — each one gives you a single digit. You must use EVERYTHING you have learned in math this year. Ready? The clock starts NOW!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where our adventure really begins! Imagine a treasure chest that's locked tight with a secret code made of six numbers. Our mission is to solve six different math puzzles, and each puzzle will give us one of those secret numbers. We'll need to use everything we've learned this whole year in math to figure them out!

slides.text: Puzzles 1-2: 'Envelope 1 is addition and subtraction. Solve carefully — one wrong calculation means a wrong code digit! Envelope 2 is multiplication. Remember your strategies: arrays, repeated addition, or the standard algorithm.'
